loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hamidan's Group

texts.en:
Hamidan is married to M. Y. who is involved in a scrap business. They all live in a city called Pakpattan in Pakistan.  She sells bangles to financially support her family. She started this business by taking a loan earlier from Asasah. 

Now she has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband who wants to increase his sales and profits by adding more scrap material to his shop. Hamidan has a son who is also a scrap dealer and works with his father in his shop. 

She is hopeful that her husband’s profits will be increased with the help of an investment that will make possible for her son to open his own scrap shop in the near future.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola is 27 years old and married with three children between the ages of 2 and 12. Two of her children are currently attending school.

Viola is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley in Kenya. She has been farming for the last year and has employed one farmhand. Her main product is milk which she sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Sotik town, Rift Valley, Kenya. She also operates a shop and a hotel (restaurant).

Her biggest challenges in farming have been lack of enough land to keep more dairy cows, lack of funds to purchase both land and dairy cows and poor pricing that keeps fluctuating.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. She says that this loan will enable the family to acquire another asset that will be used as security for subsequent loans. She will also earn extra income from the sale of milk.

In the future, she would like to improve her dairy farming by buying quality dairy cows and building a modern dairy unit. She is grateful to Juhudi for the constant support and requests more funding in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira D. is from the village of Kuguita, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 58 years old, a widow, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Elvira owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $193 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina M. is from the village of Kuguita, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she buys and sells dried fish and shrimp in the local community. Lina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $82 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Lina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lina is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Ulongoni Group

texts.en:
Esther L., age 38, is married with four children, ages 19, 17, 12 and 8 years. She has a tailoring business where she sews tablecloths and bedsheets as well as selling small snacks.  She works daily from 7am until 6pm and she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $192.

This will be Esther’s 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy a big roll of material for her business and has paid back the loan successfully.  She hopes for a loan to open a shop and start selling fabrics and sarongs. 

Esther will share this loan with her loan group, Ulongoni, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other responsible in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Esther is second from the left in an orange dress.

loans.use: To open a shop and start selling fabrics and sarongs.

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
Rosanna G. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 43 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she buys and sells dried fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosanna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosanna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
This month, Rosalinda Alejado’s business is at its peak because classes have opened and therefore a lot of students and teachers need school uniforms and/or to have their uniforms repaired.  Just recently she has received a bunch of orders. Timely, the loan she is paying through ASHI has ended and now she is qualified to request another loan. Considering the high demand for her products, Rosalinda would like to request a larger loan. 

For Rosalinda’s previous performance in ASHI, she has maintained a 100% rating in terms of repayment, attendance to weekly center meetings and her business. Aside from proving her competence to other people, Rosalinda has also discovered that she has the ability to grow her business and to be responsible in paying a loan she used as an investment in her business. Although she cannot yet say that her business is sustainable, she is positive that someday it will thrive together with her family life.

loans.use: To buy a large volume of cloth and other supplies for making and repairing school uniforms.

loans.name: Sumaira's Group

texts.en:
Sumaira belongs to a poor family living in the city of Pakpattan in Pakistan. It is not easy for an illiterate person to survive financially due to the high cost of living, but Sumaira will never give up. She started embroidering for her neighborhood clients to financially help her husband. She is also a good housewife and takes care her family very well. She is the mother of one daughter and one son, both of whom are very young and have not yet started their education. Sumaira wants to give them a quality education. That’s why she wants to save money for their secure future, but this is possible only when she has a large enough household income for saving money. 

Her husband is a fruit seller; he sells fruits from a cart. He needs more fruit to offer to his clients and for this reason Sumaira has applied for a loan from Asasah. She has been an Asasah client for the last three years and maintained good credit behavior. She hopes that this loan will be profitable like the previous ones.

loans.use: Purchase fruits for reselling

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
45-year-old Emma B. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has an eleven-year-old child. Emma owns and operates a general store. She sells both food & daily use products in the local community. She also owns a rice farm, which her husband manages. They sell their harvest at their store and to their local market. She has been doing this for over ten years now.

Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase additional products to sell at the store as well as inputs for the rice farm. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Emma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing store inventory and farm inputs

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 52 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 4 children between the ages of 10 and 33. Three of the children are still attending school.

Patrick is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 22 years and has six employees. His products are pineapples, maize, tea, and milk which he sells locally. He also buys and re-sells cows at a profit.

His biggest challenge has been the high cost of farm inputs like fertilizers and chemicals which affects his produce and the inconsistent markets and pricing of his farm products.

Patrick has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 60,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase a dairy cow. He says that with this loan, he will have more disposable income through the sale of milk and this will improve the living standards of his family.

In the future, he would like to increase the quality of his dairy breeds and purchase a truck that will assist him in transportation. He would also like to access loans of higher amounts in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en:
Ritchel T. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 26 years old, married and has a 6-year-old child. Ritchel owns and operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also runs a sari-sari store located at their house. Ritchel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. 

Ritchel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Ritchel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ritchel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Ritchel from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Shazia lives in the city called Pakpattan in Pakistan. She has applied for a fourth loan from Asasah. This time she wants to help her husband who works in the field and needs money to buy seeds and fertilizers for his land. 

She is the mother of two children who are both very young and need the fulltime attention of their mother. She is a housewife but she also sews clothes for her neighborhood clients to earn extra income for her family. 

She is a regular client of Asasah. She has maintained a good credit behavior. She has successfully completed her three loans of Asasah and now has applied for the fourth time for a loan to establish her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy the abovementioned items for his lands and produce good crops.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Chor

texts.en: Chor C., 52, sells various kinds of vegetables in a local market to earn a living. She buys the vegetables in bulk from farmers or wholesale suppliers and sells them retail to people who come to buy something for their cooking. Chor C. is married to Meng An, age 49, who shares responsibility for his family by working as a local farmer. They are good parents to their four children. One is now married, and the other three are single. Chor C. is running her business well because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Chor C. wishes to have more money to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 62 years old. He is married with 8 children between the ages of 11 and 29. Six of his children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 33 years and has employed five people from his community. His main produce is tea, pineapples, and milk which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from his rental shops and houses in the same area.

His major challenge has been lack of tapped water and this has made it hard for his dairy herd since the cows have to go to the river to take water.

Joseph has requested this second loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 80,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase a dairy cow and expand his farm under animal feed. He says that this loan will bring in more income for the family through the sale of milk and thus improve the living standards of the family and ease payment of school fees.

In the future, he would like to increase efficiency in his farm by owning machines like chaff cutters for animal feed and purchase a vehicle to aid in the transportation of his products to the market. He is also grateful to Juhudi for making available loan facilities for farmers like himself.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and expand his farm

loans.name: Otgon

texts.en:
Otgon D. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on her husband’s brother’s land. Her son, Gansukh, is 21 years old and works in construction; her daughter, Gerel, is 17 years old, and attends a secondary school.

Otgon currently operates a construction materials business out of a rented stall at the largest market in Ulaanbaatar. Since 1999, when she started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and paying for her daughter's education fees. She says, "I will work hard to repay the loan on time and I will use it to grow my business. In addition, I would like to provide a good education for my children.”

Otgon is an open and very hardworking person. She is requesting a loan to purchase inventory.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en: Reynaldo P. is from the village of Tablon, Digkilaan, Iligan City. He is 30 years old and is married with four school-aged children. Reynaldo owns and operates a fish-selling business, selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Reynaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. Dionesita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Dionesita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her fourth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. loans.name: Jemalyn

texts.en:
Jemalyn R. is from the village of Barinaut, Iligan City. She is 20 years old and is single.

Jemalyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jemalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Mrs. Sreng S. is married with five children.  She has spent her entire life cultivating crops. She learned this skill from her grandparents when she was young. Her husband frequently works in the farm fields alongside her. She has had great success growing crops. The coming rainfall is good for growing, but Sreng S. lacks capital to buy farming supplies. So Sreng S. is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Madelina

texts.en: Madelina D. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol at home and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Madelina is 30 years old and is married to a cattle farmer. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Madelina hopes to be able to open a bar and stock more crates of beer in the bar for the same business. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Ihingiro Development Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
B. Denis, hardworking and reserved 41-year-old married father of five children, has been operating a pork butchery business in Katojo trading Centre in Rukungiri district for over five years. He buys pigs from the surrounding villages which he slaughters and gets ready for selling to his genuine customers who have supported him this long.

Denis’s business has grown to the extent that he has been able to have his children undergo education. In a month, he reveals he makes close to 200,000 Ugandan shillings and also makes some additional income through his side-business.

Denis’s drawback is having a small amount of stock in his business. Therefore, he would like to use this loan to restock his business by buying more animals for his daily butcher job. His future plans are to expand his business and improve his sales revenue.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to butcher and to stock his bar

loans.name: Nura

texts.en: Nura T. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more food items to be cooked and sold in her restaurant. Nura is 39 years old and is married to a peasant farmer. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Nura hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant and stock more chairs and tables for better accommodation. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more food items to be cooked and sold in her restaurant

loans.name: William

texts.en: William M. Jr. is from the village of Tablon, Digkilaan, Iligan City. He is 34 years old and is married with three school-aged children. William owns and operates a business providing motorela or habal-habal (motorcycle transport) services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, William joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Bugongi United Savings & Credit B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Benard R.'s main source of livelihood for the past 10 years has been selling produce and foodstuffs in Bugongi, Kihihi town. It is with earnings from this business that the hardworking Benard R. has managed to sustain his family of 13 children. The 48-year-old dynamic businessman has reached a point where profits accruing to his business now amount to 300,000 Ugandan shillings in a month. With steadying progress in building his small enterprise, he reckons his future prospects are rising every passing day.

With a loan coming his way, he carries conviction that he will be able to buy more cash-crops produce like maize, cassava, peanuts, beans and rice, so that he does not run short of stock and supplies. This will improve his sales revenue and enable him to live a self-sustaining life as he looks at educating his children and they become important people who can support themselves in future.

texts.en:
Nelia M. is a 42-year-old mother of four children and a wife to Francisco. She feels privileged to have learned many things from her experiences being poor. She has learned to move on and do something to break the chain that holds her and her family to poverty. 

In 2009, Nelia joined ASHI and requested a loan to buy and sell rice and fish. When she received the amount of her initial request, her planned venture materialized and she has able to have her own income. This has been used to support the needs of her family, especially of her children, three of whom are studying — one in college, one in high school and the youngest in elementary school. 

Nelia aims to grow her business and support the education of her children until they all graduate from college. She also hopes that by increasing her profit, she will be able to start a savings fund for the other needs of her family.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
28-year-old Karen P. is a loving mother to her only offspring and a helpful child to her parents. Despite having her own family to take care of after her marriage to a 33-year-old man name Reynaldo, Karen still wants to support the needs of her parents who are old and poor.

In the light of this, and with the addition of her dream of graduating her child from college in the future, Karen wanted to start her own business to augment the income of her husband who is a hired small-time technician.

Just recently, Karen joined ASHI to request a loan that she will use as capital investment to start up a sari-sari store business. A sari-sari (variety) store basically sells small quantities of various foodstuffs, grocery items and beverages. “Sari” is a word in the native dialect of Antiquenos meaning “variety”. This is just a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away from the owner’s house. Items sold through this business bring convenience to people in the village, especially those who live far away from the town proper where the market is located.

With ASHI and the services she can obtain through her membership, Karen is hopeful that, one day, the kind of life her family has will be comfortable.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Djekabaara  2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  femmes du groupe Djekabaara 2 sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Sontiguila, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide, le petit mil et le haricot. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, FATOUMATA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare  d’arachides.
La production est vendue au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten women of the Djekabaara 2 group are all married and average 40 years of age with four children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Sontiguila, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region, which is the second administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the winter. The crops cultivated are among others peanuts, pearl millet and beans. The women are on their first farming loan from Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, Fatoumata D. is planning on buying intrants and small equipment, as well paying for the labour costs to maintain around a hectare of peanuts. The produce, once harvested, is sold in the village of Nangola and its surroundings, as well as in the town of Dioïla to a customer base made up of men and women. Fatoumata is expecting to make an average profit of 50,000FCFA for each season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants, small equipement and labour costs

loans.name: Djekabaara  3 Group

texts.fr:
Les  sept membres du groupe Djekabaara 3 sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Sontiguila, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont  l’arachide, le petit mil et le haricot. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, SITAN C. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et consommateurs. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Djekabaara 3 group are married women, who average 35 years of age and have three children each; the majority of them live in polygamous families in Sontiguila, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region, which is the second administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the winter season. The crops they cultivate are peanuts, pearl millet and beans. They are on their first farming loan from Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, Sitan C. is planning to buy intrants before prices rise, and small equipment, as well as paying the labor costs to maintain around a hectare of peanuts. The produce, once harvested, is sold in the village of Nangola and the surroundings as well as in the town of Dioïla, to a customer base made up of retailers and consumers. The women are expecting to make an average profit of 50,000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants and small equipment as well payment of labor costs

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
24-year-old Mabel A. is from the town of Bunawan. She is married and has a 7-year-old child. Mabel owns and operates a farming business. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes to be able to save for her child's future.

Mabel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Mabel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mabel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Mabel from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Operating a farm has been a tremendous business venture for B. Grace from Kakungu, Ntungamo. Having a family of ten children, of whom four are dependents, and with a not-so-caring husband who does no productive work, Grace worked tooth and nail to start up the sale of bananas alongside her milk sales from her farm. Bananas are commonly used to prepare a local dish by customers here in Uganda.

Grace is so fond of her business, which is always able to earn her 400,0000 Ugandan shillings monthly. She needs a loan to help her do the mulching, to buy stake poles for her plantation and pesticides. Furthermore, the expansion of her project to large-scale is her main motive for her business. This will help her improve her production and sales revenue to enable her to care for her family and enjoy a sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase mulches, stake poles and pesticides for her banana plantation

loans.name: Melona

texts.en:
Melona C. is from the town of Bunawan. She is 29 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Melona owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Melona has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from it.

Melona joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melona has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Melona from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Determined A. Edwin is a happily married father of 3 children, two of whom are in school. Like any other responsible man, he examined how best he could satisfy his family requirements, having previously been engaged in poultry farming. He went into agriculture and built up a banana plantation and started up a farm rearing cows, goats and sheep in his home area of Katabwigute, Ntungamo.

Having a variety of livestock on his farm makes his business more attractive and beneficial. He has been able to capture a good market for his meat from butchery owners and for his bananas from hotel owners who use them to prepare a local dish for customers. This has seen him earn 210,000 UGX on a monthly basis. His main setback is having a small stock. With this loan, he hopes to restock more animals and also modernize the farming system on the plantation. This will improve both his market supply and his sales revenue.

loans.use: to buy more cows, sheep and goats for restocking and to modernize the plantantion with fertilizers

loans.name: Irene Akinyi

texts.en: “Being  a housewife and assisting other people with petty tasks for income makes one a slave,” Irene confesses, and this is why she opted in 2009 to start a business selling vegetables in Nambale since it had a relatively high income. Her dream of expanding her business was absolutely bleak despite the business being lucrative. When this proud 23-year-old mother living in Olepito heard of the KIVA loan fund through K-MET,  her dream of developing her business came true. She applied for a loan of KES 10,000 to expand her business in her own premises to help her eradicate poverty in her family.

loans.use: to increase her stock to boost business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna runs a small business selling jeans. She started this business a few years ago on the recommendation of her friends. Affordable prices and excellent client service helped Anna to develop her business. Today, she has many repeat customers and good sales. 

Anna is single. She lives with her mother and grandmother. Anna is a highly motivated person. She works hard to develop her business further. Anna's business goal is to open a small store to sell clothing that anyone can afford.

Anna would like to receive a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase inventory for the fall season. By buying it now when the prices are low, Anna can increase the margin and make more profit. Anna's business is the only source of income for her family.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

loans.name: Felix

texts.en: Felix V. is from the town of Bunawan. He is 32 years old. Felix is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Felix raises crops. The main source of income for his business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. From selling rice, he was able to start a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife mainly manages. They sell vinegar, sugar and other products. He says he wants to have a happy family. Felix joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felix has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Felix is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the third loan taken out by Felix from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. loans.name: John Okubo

texts.en:
John Okubo, who is 40 year old, testifies how life without a job at times can be hard. This was what actually contributed to the initiation of his investment in the clothes-selling business in the year 2000 in Nambale, so that he could generate income to support his family. Despite the business being attractive, he was totally disillusioned since he could not get enough capital to expand it. He says that if he can access a loan worth 10,000 Kenyan shillings from Kiva, he will be able to adjust going to Busia and Kisumu two times a week to purchase enough so that he expands the business and widens his income base. 

A happily married father of four children, who stay in Nambale, he believes that if his request is responded to, he will absolutely build his own premise and ensure that his children’s educational pursuits are met.

loans.use: Increase stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josline Namdzini

texts.en:
Josline, 36, is the mother of five children and lives in Manyole. She started selling cereals in Nambale in the year 2005 after realizing that farming could not meet her search for independence and boost her standard of living. Despite the marvelous return from the investment, she can’t diversify the business because she lacks adequate money.

Upon learning about this wonderful contribution of the Kiva loan initiative from a friend who is a beneficiary, she applied for a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings. She is optimistic that if she can access the loan, then she will be able to add another venture (poultry-keeping) and accelerate attaining her life objective.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Pamela Atieno

texts.en:
Pamela Atieno B., 34, is married and has five children. She started a shoe-vending business in 2003 in Nambale, even though she lives in Lwanyange. This was due to increasing economic demand and, as a housewife, she could not salvage the situation since the family size was also increasing and her husband alone could not afford all the family's basic needs. As a result of influence from friends and easy accessibility to shoe supply points, she opted to start this venture. 

She tells how motivating the business is because of the returns, but her desire to expand it further isn't possible due to inadequate capital. That is why she requested a loan worth 8,000 Kenyan shillings to improve her stock level to enable her to realize a high income and to acquire land for extensive agriculture.

loans.use: Boost the business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.use: Labor costs, seeds, fertilizer, weedkiller, hoeing and small equipment

loans.name: Francis Otsiendo

texts.en:
Having worked in a construction firm for a considerable duration of time, Francis Otsiendo O. thought it wise to start a cereals business in the year 2008 in Lugulu to uplift his socio-economic status. The 33-year-old, a proud father of three who lives in Lugulu, travels to Busia on a weekly basis to restock his business. This is a venture that has had a positive impact on his life, but his aim of expanding the venture has been paralyzed due to lack of sufficient capital. 

In his quest to achieve this goal, he joined the Kiva loan scheme for a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings to expand his cereal venture and maximize his profit to enable him to initiate another venture, which will enhance his ability to provide for the essential needs for his family.

loans.use: Increase stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Irene Clare

texts.en:
Irene Clare Achieng is a businesswoman who sells clothes (kitenge). She buys her stock in Busia twice a month and sells in Nairobi. Basically, she started this business to subsidize her previous investment in farming which could not fulfill her family's needs effectively.

Irene is 28 years old, married, and a mother of three children. She tells how harsh the economy is and calls for aggressiveness. She tells how lucrative the business is, but mentions inadequate capital as a great setback for diversification. 

Her reason for joining the KIVA loan initiative was so that she could access a loan worth 10,000 KES so that she can expand her business to generate more income, which will enable her to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: Increase her stock and expand the business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 53 years old. He is married and has seven children between the ages of 6 and 24. Five of the children are attending school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for 20 years and has employed two people from his community. His products are bananas, milk, beans, maize and tea, which he sells locally and to Kenya Tea Development Authority respectively. He is also employed as a primary school teacher.

David recently completed his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of KES.75,000 to renovate his dairy unit and purchase farm supplies. The extra income from this loan will enable him provide the basic needs of his family. He intends to purchase more dairy cows in the future to increase his milk production.

He is requesting Juhudi to increase the amount of loans offered and reduce the interest rate on loans.

loans.use: To renovate his dairy unit and purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Millicent Anyango

texts.en: Millicent Anyango O. is 27 year old, married and a proud mother of four children. She lives in Lwanyange. Owing to the diverse skills she acquired during her employment period in a beauty salon, she opted to start her own salon in the year 2010 in Malanga to enhance her self-dependency and sustainability. In her prior employment, she could not adequately satisfy her family needs. This venture requires her to buy stock from the supermarket and travel to Busia once a month for additional stock because it is cheaper there. Having been given insight by loan beneficiaries, she joined K-MET so that she could access a loan worth Ksh.10000 to enable her to achieve her life goal of owning a photocopier and a barbershop.

loans.use: To boost and expand business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roselida Akwero

texts.en: Roselida Akwero A. is 45 years old, married and a proud mother of seven children. She operates a hotel (restaurant) situated in Malanga where she lives. She normally buys commodities on a daily basis from Nambale. Previously, she practiced agriculture. Due to her quest to boost her standard of living, she started the hotel(restaurant) business to increase her income. Actually, she marveled at the returns from the business, but her aspiration to diversify the enterprise was cut short due to inadequate capital. For this reason, after having been given insights by members who had benefited from the initiative, she joined K-MET to get loan funding worth Ksh 10,000 to boost her business and enable her to achieve her life goal of a better standard of living.

loans.use: To boost business by increasing stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jenipher Adhiambo

texts.en: Jenipher Adhiambo O. is a resident of Lwanyange. She is a trained tailor but later became a housewife. She could not ignore her family's needs so she started vegetable farming and selling in the year 2001 in Nambale so that she could assist her husband in supporting the family. She realized that the venture was very lucrative and was inspired to expand it further. Due to insufficient funds, she requested a loan of Ksh.10,000 to boost her business and enable her to achieve her dream of being economically independent and able to afford a quality education for her children. Jenipher, who is 30 years old, married and a mother of four children is optimistic that her life will improve if she receives the loan.

loans.use: To boost her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Julia Anyango

texts.en: Julia Anyango O. is married with four children. She is 34 years old. She is a business lady who sells second hand clothes that she normally buys from Busia. She is situated in Malanga. Prior to this, she practiced agricultural activities, which she realized could not enable her to adequately satisfy all her family needs and that is why, when she heard of this initiative of loan grants by K-MET, she decided to apply for a loan worth Ksh.10000. She will use the loan to increase her stock so that she can expand her business and maximize her profit to help improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anthony Osiago

texts.en: Anthony Osiago O. is a married man with five children. To support his family, Anthony had a cane farming business. He recalls how daunting cane cutting tasks were and this is what actually compelled him to initiate his venture growing and selling beans in the year 2006 in Nambale, even though he stays in Lwanyange. Anthony, who travels twice in a week to Busia to add more stock, has a strong desire to develop himself but highlights inadequate capital as a challenge that has deterred him from expanding the enterprise. For this reason, he opted to join K-MET to access a loan of Kes 10,000 to enable him to expand his business, plough back the profit and engage in dairy farming.

loans.use: To boost his business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peter Mark

texts.en: Peter Mark A. is 28 years old, married and a father of four children. He lives in Nambale, Busia. Peter used to do farming, which he quit in 2005 and started selling clothing. He travels twice a week to Busia town to purchase his stock. Despite this, the business does not generate enough income to enable him to attain his lifetime objectives of affording quality education for his children and gaining economic stability. Peter decided to join K-MET where he has applied for a loan of Ksh.10,000, which will help him boost his business and attract more income.

loans.use: To increase his stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Agness Nasumiyu

texts.en: Agness Nasumiyu N., 45 year old, is married with seven children and stays in Nambale, Busia. Agness could not withstand the economic dependency on her husband anymore and decided to start selling vegetables and potatoes in 2007. She buys her stock in Nambale and Butula twice a week. Upon learning of the wonderful contribution of KMET micro finance and KIVA, she joined so that she could get a loan of Ksh.10,000 to boost her business and later achieve her dreams of expanding the venture and constructing rental houses to enable her to uplift her economic standards.

loans.use: To Increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Moses Odhiambo

texts.en: Moses Odhiambo O. is 34 years old. He operates a hotel (restaurant) business that he started in 2007. He lives in Nambale, Busia and is married with four children. Before he began his business, Moses used to be a farmer and with increased economic pressure, he saw the need to expand his business venture so that he could increase his income. He decided to join KMET micro finance initiative to enable him get a loan of Ksh.10000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To boost his business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mukunyu Twekambe Group

texts.en:
Doreen, 37 years old and a mother of four children, is married and lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. She has been dealing in bridal rental services for four years. She started small but the business has grown over time and she expects it to grow even more. Bridal businesses have grown of recent in the country as people want to make their marriage days colorful and memorable. Doreen wants a loan to purchase bridal gowns.

Doreen is a member of Mukunyu Twekambe group in Kyenjojo, Uganda in which each member guarantees the other for access to credit since most of them do not have collateral security to pledge. It works out in a way that each member knows the credibility and character of the others.

loans.use: To purchase bridal gowns for hire

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes T. currently sells green vegetables such as okra, cabbage, sukumawiki (kale), etc., at the marketplace and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish and fresh Irish potatoes to sell.

Agnes is 24 years old, is married to a driver, and has two children who still stay at home without studying.

With the extra profits from her loan, Agnes will double her effort to provide comfort for her family by providing them with basic needs and by sending her children to school.

loans.use: To stock dried fish and fresh Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man with two girls, nine and three years old, who both attend school.

Joseph has been operating his meat goat business for the last seven years and with the Kshs 40,000, he wants to purchase five goats for meat sale. He does farming as his other source of livelihood and sells fruit. His main customers are the neighboring community and passersby.

Joseph faces the major challenges of seasonality and high transport costs. He rents a house with no electricity nor piped water and his greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and rent.

Joseph hopes that someday he will open a retail business. He joined Yehu so as to access loans and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase five meat goats for sale

loans.name: Janylkan

texts.en:
Janylkan M., 34, is married and is the mother of two school-age children: her daughter is 15 and her son is 12. She’s been married to Emilbek Risbaev for fifteen years. Janylkan is a very persistent, honest and optimistic woman who strives hard to provide her children with everything they need.

Janylkan works in wholesale and retail sales of vegetables and her husband supports her business by collecting goods from different regions. In the summer, when some kinds of goods perish more quickly, Janylkan works day and night to provide good-quality products to her loyal customers.

Janylkan started her business in 2000 with the sum of 1,000 KGS. Now, she earns the sum of 15,000 KGS monthly, which allowed her to purchase a small house in Sokuluk village (near Kyrgyzstan, the capital).

In May, 2010, Janylkan had a car accident and was injured - she hit her head and got a scar on her face. She spent a lot of money for surgery and treatment, which led to a decrease in her working capital. In spite of these complications, she is moving forward and applying for a loan. Using this loan, she plans to increase her current capital in order to purchase carrots to sell wholesale. It will allow her to reach the business level that she had before the accident.

In the future, Janylkan wants to buy a truck to deliver her products in a cheaper and easier way. She also plans to buy sheep for fattening and resale. These investments will help her to support her children and give them a good education.

loans.use: To purchase carrots to sell wholesale

loans.name: Adila

texts.ru:
Adile 36 qoda .Ona jivet v qorode Baku. Na risunke vi mojete videt brata Adili (Rovshan) s kotorim ona jivet vmeste. Ona bila zamujem no posle razriva teper jivet s bratom i rabotayet vmeste snim v odnom biznese.Adila uje zanimayetsya etim biznesem 6 let a yeyo brat 7 let. Ona ne imeyet detey. 

Seychas Adila nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji . V sobstvennosti ona xotelabi kupit moyushiye sredstva dlya tarelok dlya odejdi dlya uborki doma.
texts.en:
Adila is 36 years old. She lives in the city of Baku. On the picture you can see Adila’s brother Rovshan, who lives together with her. Adila was married in the past but after the separation from her husband she has been living with her brother and working in the same business with him. She has been in business for six years already, and her brother for seven years. She doesn’t have children. At present Adila needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to buy goods for resale. More specifically, she would like to buy different types of detergents: for dishwashing, for doing the laundry and for household cleaning.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying goods for resale

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen K., who is 48 years old, has a business selling bags of maize flour, tomatoes, and peeled, dried cassava at the market. She requested a loan in order to stock bags of pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas, etc.) to sell.

Hellen is widowed and has only a son who does not go to school. In the future, Hellen wants to see her son married.

loans.use: To stock bags of pulses to sell

loans.name: Roza

texts.ru:
Roza jivet v Absheron regioane. Yey 41 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 2 detey.Yeyo deti 17 i 20 let . Oni uchatsya ochen xorosho. Roze v etom biznese pomoqayet i muj  on pomoqayet yey privozit noviye tovari iz "Locbatan".

Roza uje 8 let v etom biznese .Teper ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi rasshirit prostranstvo i sdelat remont.
Ona qovorit chto yey ne xvatayet mesta dlya yeyo tovarov tak kak mnoqo novix modeley ona privozit.
texts.en:
Roza lives in the Absheron Region. She is married and has two children. Her children are 17 and 20 years old. They are very good students. Roza’s husband helps her out with the business too, delivering new goods from the Locbatan [Region]. Roza has been in this business for eight years already. She now needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to expand and renovate her store. She says that she does not have enough space for her goods as she gets many new models delivered.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to expand the store

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona P. is in the business of selling bread, tomatoes and cooking oil at the market and is requesting a loan so as to stock dried fish to sell.

Lona is a woman whose husband died a long time ago and she has four children who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she intends to sustain her family by providing them with the basic needs and by providing food security at home.

loans.use: To stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a married man with one son who is 2 years old and too young for school. He has been operating his goat meat business for the last two years. With the 40,000 KES he wants to purchase ten goats for meat sales. Previously he was a hawker. The challenges he faces are high transport costs and seasonality. His other source of income is his food stall business.

Richard rents a house with electricity but no piped water. He cites food, medication and rent as his greatest monthly expenses. He decided to work with YEHU in order to access loans and improve his standard of living. Richard hopes to start a dairy farm business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase ten goats for meat sales

loans.name: Jokudu

texts.en:
Jokudu M. sells ice cream and bread at the market and is requesting a loan to stock baking flour to start baking local Sudanese bread to sell.  

Jokudu is 39 years old, married to a teacher, and has three children who all go to school.  In the future, she hopes to open a restaurant if any extra profits are realized from her business.

loans.use: to stock baking flour

loans.name: Shahlar

texts.ru:
Shahlaru 29 let . On jivet v Absheron regione . Shahlar jenat i imeyet 3 detey kotorim 5,7 i 10 let .On uje 5 let zanimayetsya etim biznesom . On xochet uludshit biznes i uvelichit svoy daxod chtobi on moq obespechit xoroshuyu jizn svoim detam i chtob eqo deti imeli vozmojnost dlya xoroshey uchebi. 

Seychas Shahlar nujdayetysa v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit mnoqo novix tkaney rulonami dlya pereprodaji i uludsheniye eqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Shahlar is 29 years old. He lives in the Absheron Region. He is married and has three children: five, seven and ten years of age. He has been in this business for five years. He would like to enhance his business and increase his income in order to be able to improve the life conditions of his children and provide them with good education. At present Shahlar needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats to purchase many rolls of new fabrics for resale, which will allow him to enhance his business.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing rolls of fabric for resale

loans.name: Kigarama Kwetungura, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
As they say, determination is a key to success. B. Benon, a happily married father of six children, ventured into tea growing in Kigarama, Kihihi, twenty years ago. After realizing a readily available market in the area with a tea factory, he developed interest in growing and selling tea leaves alongside his farming business. This enterprise sees him earning about $41 a month which has had a great impact on his standard of living. 

His main problem is that his land is infertile and produces low yields. With this loan he is looking at buying fertilizer and manure as well as further expanding his tea plantation by buying more seedlings and planting on a large scale. This will improve his yields and his sales and enable him to take care of his family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase tea seedlings and fertilizers for plantation expansion.

loans.name: Sejerina

texts.en: Sejerina J. is currently selling both fresh and sour milk at the market and has requested a loan to stock more milk to sell.  She is married to a cattleman. Sejerina has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she needs to buy some cows to add to those at home.

loans.use: Stock more milk to sell

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Operating an agricultural farm has been a tremendous business venture for Alex B. from Rugazi, Ntungamo. Being a single, energetic and determined young man who is currently in the teaching profession, he has worked tooth and nail to start up the sale of bananas, which are commonly used to prepare a local dish by customers here in Uganda.

He is fond of his enterprise and is always able to earn about $37 monthly. This loan is to help him do the mulching and to buy stake poles and pesticides for his plantation. His major future move is the further expansion of the project to a large scale. This will help to improve Alex’s yields and production, creating an increase in sales revenue that will enable him enjoy a self-sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: purchase of mulches and banana plantation supplies

loans.name: Musahibe

texts.ru:
Musahibe jivet v Absheron regione . Ona zamujem i imeyet 2 detey . Yey uje 51 qoda. Eyo deti uje kajdiy imeyet svoyu semyu. Musahibe jivet s mujom,s sinom i yeqo jenoy. Na fotoqrafii vi mojete videt sina Musahibi (Elmir) on uje 8 let v etom biznese. 

SEychas oni nujdayutsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit apchasti dlya mashini potomu chto ona isportilas i v smeyu idet ochen malo doxoda. Chtobi uvelichit doxoq on doljen ispravit mashinu v blijaysheye vremya.Tak je oni nujdayutsya v uvelicheniye doxoda pootmu chto eqo jena jdet rebonka.
texts.en:
Musahibe lives in the Absheron Region. She is married and has two children. She is 51 years old. Her children already have own families. Musahibe lives with her husband, their son and daughter-in-law. On the photo you can see Musahibe’s son, Emir, who has been in this business for eight years. At present he needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to buy spare parts for his car because it needs to be repaired, and so he cannot earn enough income for his family. In order to increase his income, he needs to have the car repaired as soon as possible. In addition, he needs to earn a bigger income because his wife is expecting a child.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married and has one small daughter. She runs a small business selling curtains and fabrics. Her kiosk is located at Obraztsovyi open market. Her good location brings in many customers. Regina's monthly net profit is about $507.

Regina started this business five years ago. She learned very fast that having a large assortment is very important to making good sales. She has used loans to purchase more inventory and to increase the assortment. This time Regina is asking for a loan of 7,500 UAH. She hopes to make additional profit to spend on a one-week family vacation.

loans.use: to increase the assortment

loans.name: Kanyantorogo Twekambe Women's, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working and die-hard agriculturalist Edith K., age 49 years, has been maintaining a banana plantation and coffee plantation for more than ten years in Burema, Kihihi. This fetches her about $89 per month, though not enough to sustain her family of six children who are pursuing their education at higher institutions of learning. 

She has persevered at keeping her enterprise growing. Her aim for taking up this loan is to enable her to buy mulches and fertilizers for her plantations and also to hire additional laborers.  She is looking at an expansion plan and wanting to transport her products to bigger markets. This will help Edith increase productivity and also earn more revenue, allowing her to be able to live a more sustainable life.

loans.use: purchase fertilizer, mulches and other farm supplies

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity G. sells dresses, bedsheets, trousers and so on at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock coats and suits to sell.  

She is 41 years old, married to a secretary in the ministry of mining and industry, and has five children who all go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start up a dry cleaning shop.

loans.use: Stock coats and suits to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase natural gas conversion kit for his Taxi

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes D., 35 years old, is currently in the business of selling maize, millet, sorghum and peeled, dried cassava at the market.  She is taking out a loan to stock bags of maize flour and beans to sell.  

She is married to a businessman and has three children, two of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a store for selling her products.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Bugongi Savings & Credit A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
M. Hope aged 48 years is married and a determined and very hard working mother of 9 children. She has been operating a retail shop business for 13 years selling general merchandise in Bugongi, Kihihi. She started her business after joining a community banking group that helped her to get operating capital. At the end of every month she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 400,000 Ugandan shillings. Her main drawback has been having a small inventory that cannot match the consumption rate of her customers. 

Hope is therefore seeking a loan that will help her stock more goods to satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform her enterprise into a wholesale business in future. Being very committed to the business and with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and meet her family requirements especially fulfilling  her dream of educating her children.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for the business

loans.name: Lenny

texts.es:
La Sra. Lenny C. tiene 20 años, está casada hace más de tres años con el Sr. Hugo Padilla Ayala, tienen una hija de 1 año de edad. Todavía viven en casa de los padres en una zona lechera y agrícola por excelencia.

La Sra. Lenny se dedica a la lechería desde hace 5 años, toda su producción de leche entrega a una empresa que elabora productos lácteos que posteriormente venden en el mercado local. 

El primer crédito que requirió fue utilizado para comprar una ordeñadora, este equipo facilitará el trabajo haciéndolo mas eficiente y fácil. Ahora desea poder adquirir otro crédito para poder comprar una vaca lechera mas y de esa manera poder incrementar su producción de  leche cruda. En el primer crédito que obtuvo Lenny demostró mucha responsabilidad con los pagos y es por esta razón que desea que la gente de Kiva confié una vez más en ella. Y agradece a todos los que la ayudaron anterior mente y confiaron en ella.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lenny C. is 20, and has been married for three years to Hugo Padilla Ayala for more than three years. Together they have a 1 year old daughter. They still live with parents in an area known for it's excellent dairy and agricultural production. Lenny has been working in the dairy industry for the past 5 years. She delivers all her milk to a local company that processes dairy products and sells them in the local market. Her first loan was used to purchase a milking machine which made her work easier and more efficient. Now she hopes to get another loan to purchase another dairy cow to increase her production of raw milk. Lenny showed great responsibility in repaying her first loan and for that reason hopes the Kiva folks with trust her once again. She thanks all of those that helped and trusted her previously.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Eliabeth

texts.en: Eliabeth P. sells different types of women dresses, head dresses, necklaces, and earring at her shop. She is requesting a loan to stock bedsheets and women sandles to sell.  Eliabeth is 35 years old and married to a head teacher. She has 3 children who all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

loans.use: To stock bedsheets and women sandles to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a happily married man with one son who is seven years old and attends school. He operates a poultry business, buying chickens and feeding them for sale of both chicken eggs and meat. He rents a house with electricity, but no piped water. With the Kshs 40,000 loan,  he wants to purchase supplies of chicken, maize and nutrient-rich feed from commercial firms. John faces the major challenge of poor husbandry and high priced feed.

He hopes to buy his own plot of land and build his own home someday. He decided to work with Yehu to access loans and improve his business. He cites food, school fees and rent as his greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of chicken , maize and nutrient-rich feed from commercial firms.

loans.name: Charles Ayieko

texts.en: Charles Ayieko W. is a cereal dealer, a business he started in 2008 after retirement from municipal council. He stays in Nambale Busia where he carries out extensive farming and takes his produce to Busia and Butula for sale. Charles, who is 66 years of age, is married and has twelve children. He was inspired with the fact that the demand of cereals in the market is increasing. Charles has requested a KIVA loan worth Ksh.10000 so that he can increase his stock and adequately maintain supplies to boost his income and realize his life's dream of owning a posho mill and being economically stable.

loans.use: Increase supplies for farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is the 27-year-old father of a two-year-old child. He sells charcoal to earn a living. He was previously employed and decided to venture into business so as to earn a better income.

Boniface has engaged in his charcoal selling business for four years and hopes to expand the business into a wholesale operation in the future. He has requested for 20,000 KES to add to his stock of charcoal.

loans.use: To add to his stock of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy construction materials like cement and cinder blocks to build a drainage system for her home

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a member of the Makima Group of Faulu Kenya. She is a married lady with two children aged 5 and 3.

Ruth sells second-hand clothes in an open-air market, where her stall is made of iron sheets. She has engaged in this business for three years, having previously operated a general store. She also does printing and photocopying for a fee to earn extra income.

Ruth has seen her business grow since she took out a loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya which she used to add stock. Her group members guaranteed her loan and she managed to repay.

Ruth is requesting another loan of 60,000 KES to add to her stock of nightwear. She also hopes get fashionable clothes such as children’s clothes, trousers and blouses to sell.

Ruth is a hardworking lady who dreams of expanding her business premises in the future.

loans.use: To buy children's clothes, trousers and blouses and to add to her stock of nightwear

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 42 years old and is married with two children, aged 2 and 6. One child goes to school.

Richard has been doing vehicle repair for six years in his garage. In addition, he is employed and therefore he has hired two people to assist him in the business.

Richard joined Faulu Kenya under a group where he can save his money and easily access loans. In this group, the members are responsible for a member who takes out a loan. Therefore, Richard has requested a loan of 20,000 KES through the group to purchase mechanic’s tools.

Richard hopes to expand his garage in the future. In five years, he wants to leave his employment and concentrate fully on his business for better returns.

loans.use: To purchase mechanic's tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy painting materials to paint her house

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is 37 years old, is married, and is the father of two, aged 2 and 3.

Justus has been operating a taxi business for only one year. He was previously employed but decided to go into business to earn more income.

Currently, Justus’s vehicle is not in good condition. Hence he is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to repair it. He hopes to buy another car in the future so as to serve many customers for better returns.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 35-year-old married woman with two children aged 2 and 3. She has been selling clothes for five years to earn a living and also farms to earn extra income.

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Beatrice has become focused on her business. She has been saving money with a group in Faulu Kenya and has to set aside money from the business every week.

In the group, the members are responsible for each member who takes out a loan. Hence, Beatrice is requesting 20,000 KES through the group and will use this money to buy more clothes to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy materials to build a wall at his house to have better security for his family

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is a married man with two school-aged children. He operates Gitiyo Butchery to earn a living and has two employees. He has been in this business for four years, having previously been in farming.

Since he joined Step By Step group in Faulu Kenya, Solomon has hope for his business. This is because the group members share business ideas. Most of all, he can be guaranteed a loan from Faulu Kenya with the group and, in this way, he is able to improve his business.

Solomon has requested 20,000 KES to buy cows for slaughter. For more income, he hopes to expand his business using his savings with the group. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy cows for slaughter

loans.name: Damaso

texts.es:
El Sr. Dámaso  tiene 48 años de edad es casado y tiene 4 hijos dos  en edad escolar y dos ya mayores de edad vive en la ciudad de Carapeguá compañía Espartilla.
Don Dámaso  trabaja como artesano en su casa y con la ayuda de su esposa fabrican artesanías como ponchos, hamacas, frazadas y otros. 
Ellos cada día dedican varias horas  para fabricar los producto que luego salen a vender a los negocios de varias zonas del país.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías (hamacas, frazadas, fajas y sábanas) puesto que tiene muchos pedidos de estos productos.
texts.en:
Mr. Dámaso is 48-years-old, married, and has 4 school-aged children and 2 older children. He lives in the city of Carapeguá, Espartilla company. Mr. Dámaso works as an artisan in his house, and, with the help of his wife, makes handmade goods such as ponchos, hammocks, blankets, and other things. Each day they spend several hours making their products that they then sell at businesses in various regions of the country. He's asking for the loan to buy merchandise (hammocks, blankets, belts, and sheets) because he has many requests for these products.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beadspreads, sheets, hammocks, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for the labor on the construction of a room for his house

loans.name: Jackbed

texts.en:
Jackbed is a 36-year-old married lady who has an embroidery business. She makes tablecloths and also does embroidery work for other tailors for a fee. She has been in this business for two years.

Jackbed previously took out a loan of 20,000 KES which was guaranteed by the members of Joy Group in Faulu Kenya. This loan made her business grow and she now employs one person.

Jackbed needs to purchase another embroidery machine for faster and better services to her customers. Therefore, she has requested 40,000 KES. She hopes to expand her business and employ more people. She sees herself opening a textile and accessories shop in five years time.

loans.use: To buy another embroidery machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Herlinda

texts.es: Herlinda, de 37 años, es una mujer alegre y emprendedora que vive con su pareja Walter de 38 años, con quien tiene 2 hermosos hijos. Está familia vive juntos en su casa propia. Sus dos hijos son su motivación para esmerarse en el trabajo cada día, por eso desde hace 5 años, se dedica a cultivar café y plátano, además es negociante de frutas oriundas de la selva peruana, siendo éstas adquiridas de sus vecinos que producen dichas frutas, de las cuales compra, los encajona y los traslada hacia los mercados de “Huancayo” y “Lima” para su comercialización. Por otro lado su cónyuge brinda el servicio de transporte público, y durante los días que descansa, ayuda a Herlinda en la agricultura y en el negocio. Ella disfruta de la tranquilidad del campo, sin embargo le parece difícil tener que trasladar sus productos hasta los mercados, por eso los acopia lo cosechado en su tienda. Aunque este oficio, no la desalienta le parece sacrificado pero a la vez rentable, porque gracias a las utilidades, puede brindarle una adecuada calidad de vida a su familia, por tal motivo piensa continuar plantando café pero sobre todo incrementar y surtir de productos en su establecimiento. Esta es la segunda  vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y asegura que continuará laborando de manera activa en su grupo comunal. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará más frutas para continuar con la comercialización al por mayor y además comprar llantas para el carro de su esposo.
texts.en:
Herlinda, age 37, is a happy and enterprising woman. She lives with her life partner, 38 year old Walter, and their two beautiful children. This family lives together in their own house. Her two children are the motivation for her to do her best at work everyday. She has been growing coffee and bananas for five years. Also, she is a businesswoman selling fruit from the Peruvian jungle. She gets them from her neighbors who produce these fruits. She buys them, boxes them, and takes them to the Huancayo and Lima markets to sell. Her life partner offers public transportation services. On his days off he helps Herlinda with the farming and in the business. She enjoys the tranquility of the fields. Nevertheless, it is difficult for her to take her products to the markets. That is why she stocks her store with the harvest. Even though this job does not discourage her, it is seemingly self-sacrificing. At the same time it is profitable. Thanks to the profits she is able to give an adequate quality of life to her family. That is why she plans to continue planting coffee, and most of all, she will increase her products and stock her establishment with them. This is her second loan with MFP. She pledges to continue working in an active manner in her communal bank. She will use the requested loan to buy more fruit in order to continue selling it wholesale. She will also buy tires for her husband’s car.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more fruit and sell it wholesale

loans.name: Jason

texts.en:
Jason is a 27-year-old married man with a three-year-old child. He has been rearing chickens for five years and mainly rears layers for eggs which he sells in the local community.

Jason has been an active member of Faulu Kenya under a group and he saves money with the group on a weekly basis. He previously took out a loan of 20,000 KES to boost his business. He has requested another loan of 40,000 KES to buy chicken feeds. He hopes to supply eggs wholesale in the future.

loans.use: To buy chicken feeds

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 26-year-old married lady with a one-year-old child. She operates New Fashion Designs shop and has been in this business for five years.
